stem: The patient's condition is deteriorating. Based on the information provided in the patient's chart, which of the following interventions should the nurse prioritize?

itemContext.sbar: S: John Smith, 68-year-old male, admitted 3 days ago with acute ischemic stroke. Blood pressure has been labile. B: History of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking. Received tPA upon arrival. A: At 0700, patient became increasingly agitated and unresponsive. GCS score decreased from 14 to 9. Right-sided weakness worsening. Pupils unequal: left 4mm, reactive; right 6mm, sluggish. Vitals: BP 210/110 mmHg, HR 55 bpm, RR 10, SpO2 92% on 2L NC. Noted new onset of irregular breathing pattern. Neurosurgeon notified. R: STAT CT head ordered. Elevate HOB to 30 degrees. Prepare for possible intubation and transfer to CT. Anticipate orders for mannitol or hypertonic saline. Monitor closely for further neurological changes. Notify neurosurgeon immediately of any significant deterioration. Continuous cardiac monitoring in place. Strict I&O. Consider labetalol or nicardipine IV for BP control.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content: S: John Smith, 68-year-old male, admitted 3 days ago with acute ischemic stroke. Blood pressure has been labile. B: History of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking. Received tPA upon arrival. A: At 0700, patient became increasingly agitated and unresponsive. GCS score decreased from 14 to 9. Right-sided weakness worsening. Pupils unequal: left 4mm, reactive; right 6mm, sluggish. Vitals: BP 210/110 mmHg, HR 55 bpm, RR 10, SpO2 92% on 2L NC. Noted new onset of irregular breathing pattern. Neurosurgeon notified. R: STAT CT head ordered. Elevate HOB to 30 degrees. Prepare for possible intubation and transfer to CT. Anticipate orders for mannitol or hypertonic saline. Monitor closely for further neurological changes. Notify neurosurgeon immediately of any significant deterioration. Continuous cardiac monitoring in place. Strict I&O. Consider labetalol or nicardipine IV for BP control.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: Na: 140 mEq/L, K: 4.1 mEq/L, Cl: 100 mEq/L, HCO3: 24 mEq/L, BUN: 18 mg/dL, Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL, Glucose: 110 mg/dL, PT: 13 seconds, INR: 1.1, PTT: 30 seconds, Platelets: 250,000/uL, WBC: 8,000/uL, Hgb: 14 g/dL, Hct: 42%, ABG: pH 7.30, PaCO2 50 mmHg, PaO2 70 mmHg, HCO3 24 mEq/L, SaO2 92%.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: 0600: BP 160/90 mmHg, HR 70 bpm, RR 14, SpO2 95% on 2L NC, Temp 98.6째F (37째C), GCS 14. 0700: BP 210/110 mmHg, HR 55 bpm, RR 10, SpO2 92% on 2L NC, Temp 98.6째F (37째C), GCS 9.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Scheduled: Aspirin 81mg PO daily, Atorvastatin 40mg PO daily, Lisinopril 20mg PO daily. PRN: Acetaminophen 650mg PO q4h PRN pain/fever, Ondansetron 4mg IV q6h PRN nausea/vomiting.

rationale.correct: Administering hypertonic saline addresses the increased ICP by drawing fluid from the interstitial space into the intravascular space, thereby reducing cerebral edema. Intubation and mechanical ventilation are crucial to manage the patient's declining respiratory status (RR 10, PaCO2 50 mmHg) and maintain adequate oxygenation. Elevating the head of the bed to 30 degrees promotes venous drainage from the brain, which helps to reduce ICP. Continuous neurological assessment is essential to monitor for further deterioration and to evaluate the effectiveness of interventions. Notifying the physician of the change in status ensures timely intervention and adjustments to the treatment plan. The patient's elevated blood pressure requires prompt management to prevent further neurological damage; antihypertensive medications such as labetalol or nicardipine are typically used.
rationale.incorrect: Administering Acetaminophen for pain/fever is not the priority in this situation. While fever can increase metabolic demands and potentially worsen neurological outcomes, addressing the increased ICP and respiratory compromise are more immediate concerns. Administering Ondansetron for nausea/vomiting is not the priority. While nausea and vomiting can increase ICP, directly addressing the increased ICP and respiratory compromise are more immediate. Increasing oxygen flow rate to 6L via nasal cannula will not be sufficient to correct the hypoxemia and hypercapnia indicated by the ABGs; intubation and mechanical ventilation are required. Administering scheduled Aspirin is contraindicated during an acute deterioration related to increased ICP and potential hemorrhagic conversion. It can increase the risk of bleeding.
clinicalPearls: Rapid neurological assessment and intervention are critical in patients with suspected increased ICP.
Hypertonic saline is often preferred over mannitol in patients with impaired renal function.
Early intubation and mechanical ventilation can prevent secondary brain injury from hypoxia and hypercapnia.
Hypertension in acute stroke must be carefully managed to maintain cerebral perfusion without exacerbating ICP.

questionTrap.trap: The question focuses on immediate priorities, so test-takers might be tempted to choose options that are generally appropriate for stroke patients but not crucial in this acute deterioration.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully assess the patient's current vital signs, lab values, and neurological status to identify the most life-threatening issues. Focus on interventions that directly address increased ICP and respiratory compromise.

mnemonic.title: I-CARE-BP
mnemonic.expansion: Increased ICP - Critical Actions Require Evaluation and Blood Pressure control: Intubate if needed; Control BP; Assess Neuro status; Raise HOB; Evaluate labs; Pressure (BP) management.

options.label: Intubate and mechanically ventilate the patient.
Increase oxygen flow rate to 6L via nasal cannula.
Elevate the head of the bed to 30 degrees.
Notify the physician of the change in status.
